title: Akarana Eatery
excerpt: There are few places where you have a first-class meal, the best coffee, amazing views of Rangitoto Island and can launch a boat from – …
content:
There are few places where you have a first-class meal, the best coffee, amazing views of Rangitoto Island and can launch a boat from – insert Akarana eatery.

This beautiful all-day eatery is a collaboration between Nic Watt and the Royal Akarana Yacht Club, bringing something exciting to Orakei. Situated off the main path of Tamaki Drive just past Okahu Bay, this place offers ample parking and easy access to grab a coffee, stroll along the waterfront and soak in the scenery.

Their menu has a strong focus on fresh seafood and for their coffee, the’re serving the Allpress Espresso Blend.

Whether you’re looking for a beautiful brunch, a glass of wine in the sun or a stroll along the ocean with a flat white, Akarana Eatery is the spot for you.

more_content:
To those of you who live north of the city and spend what seems like an eternity commuting to your morning coffee, your prayers have been answered. Enter Midpoint cafe in Hobsonville.

In prime position on the busy intersection of Hobsonville Rd and Downdens Lane, this cafe makes its presence known. Perhaps this is the reason that from day one, this place has been full of people looking to get their hands on their delicious food and perfectly made coffee.

This stunning cafe is not the first for owners Banu and Sulo. They’re the couple behind the Black Cottage cafe in Coatesville and have clearly brought their refined skills to give the quickly growing community of Hobsonville a place to meet every morning. They teamed up with the builders that were behind such well known spots as Mary’s and Amano to make ensure the space has a feeling of quality. This can be seen in the striking walnut bench top that spans the length of the service area.

Serving up Allpress Espresso Blend, if you’re looking for a new place to park up, look no further.

excerpt: The diversity of Asia is well represented on Zion Road. Just across the road from a modern shopping mall is a row of traditional shophouses, …
content:
The diversity of Asia is well represented on Zion Road. Just across the road from a modern shopping mall is a row of traditional shophouses, one of which we’ve called home since 2015. This central location means we can supply delicious coffee from our Melbourne roastery across the country and to the rest of South-East Asia.

As with our other spaces, our shop house was transformed from a run-down shell to a bright, beautiful and functional space. Here, we keep up with our technical, training and customer service support as well as hosting visitors and customers alike.

Although we don’t have a café here, please give us a call to arrange a visit; we’ll have the coffee hot and waiting.

title: Burrow Cafe
excerpt: A special spot tucked away in the quintessential Australian town of Toowoomba, Tasch and Clem recently opened the doors of Burrow and is quickly becoming a community favourite.
content:
Tucked away in the regional, quintessential Australian town of Toowoomba, 130 km west of Brisbane, you’ll find Burrow Cafe. Tasch and Clem have recently opened the doors to Burrow and it is already becoming a community favourite with a space designed to bring people together and a menu created to keep everyone coming back for more.

Toowoomba is a historical town and with that being said, the building that Burrow has found itself in has been everything from a pet-grooming store to an ice cream parlour in the 1950’s and locals love the storytelling. The cafe pays homage to the history with a fit-out of locally recycled furniture and old timber from torn down houses in the area, making the cafe fit into the residential setting nicely. And if you feel like relaxing in some Queensland Sunshine while sipping your coffee, there is a beautiful backyard for that.

The menu caters for breakfast, brunch and lunch and is a menu that follows the seasons with ever-changing specials and something tasty for the gluten-free and vegan customers too. If you’re extra hungry, the ‘All-in’ big breaky comes highly recommended or for something sweet, the ricotta doughnuts will hit the spot. But with Tasch’s background in hospitality and food from different cultures, her sister as the in-house baker and Clem’s French origins – the menu is built by women who know what they’re doing!

The Allpress team in Brisbane are exceptionally excited to be working with Tasch and Clem at Burrow. When we first met them in person early in 2018, their story of first tasting our coffee at Harvest in Newrybar, loving it and keeping an Allpress coaster for the day they open their own cafe is a special one for us.

subtitle: この地域でもっとエスプレッソやコーヒースタンドのカルチャーを広めたい
title: Maruni Shoten
excerpt: 美味しいものに出会えるユニークなかんぶつカフェ
content:
千葉県は市川市にオープンしたまるに商店。もともとこのスペースはもう一つのビジネスである海苔製品を製造するための工場と倉庫の役割を担っていました。それをスタッフみんなでリノベーションしてコーヒーとかんぶつのお店にしたそう。”かんぶつ”と言っても海苔や野菜をはじめナッツやフルーツまで、店内にはこだわりの商品が並ぶ。コーヒーとかんぶつ？って思うかもしれないけれどコーヒーだってかんぶつだよね、と言うのは伊藤さん。

オーナーの伊藤さんは毎日築地でお仕事をしながらも、カフェに顔を出したりオールプレスのパーフェクトカップに参加したりと、コーヒーのことを一生懸命に学んでくれています。この地域でももっとエスプレッソやコーヒースタンドのカルチャーを広めたい、そういう想いでこれからも様々な活躍が期待できる伊藤さんはオールプレスの大切な仲間です。

自慢のかんぶつを使ったパウンドケーキやクッキーなどはすべてお店で手作り。かんぶつを買いに来る常連さんがコーヒーも飲んでくれる、と話すバリスタのエスプレッソはオールプレスも納得の一杯です。美味しいものに出会えるユニークなかんぶつカフェまるに商店に立ち寄ってみてはいかが？

title: Little Pom’s Cafe
excerpt: A real mouthful.
content:
Little Pom’s Cafe has a commanding presence in the Garden City; specialising in delicious food, lovely coffee and brilliant service! Little Pom’s absolutely takes care of your soul with the way they host you, with their own style that is well above the rest.

The food is seasonal, focussing on locally sourced, organic, fresh ingredients from artisan producers. There’s something for everyone on the menu – from Steel cut oats with poached organic apple, rhubarb, banana, cardamom custard, chocolate caramel crumble to Pulled Chinese beef brisket, pickled vegetables, spring onions, kimchi mayo, brioche roll.

A must-visit when you’re in Christchurch, and a real mouthful.

content:
長野県は野沢温泉村、その温泉街の中心にあるホテルが Haus St. Anton です。そして３年以上もの間オールプレスのコーヒーを淹れてくれています。

ホテルの一階にあるカフェ＆ショップではオールプレスのコーヒーをはじめ、Haus St. Anton の手作りのおいしさに溢れたスペース。一押しは自家製ジャム、桃や林檎などを使った無添加のジャムは東京ロースタリー＆カフェでも楽しむことができます。それに加えてジェラートや野沢菜を使ったお焼きなど、シェフのこだわりが詰まったものばかり。

また野沢温泉スキー場にもコーヒーキオスクを出している Haus St. Anton。スキーやスノーボードを楽しんだらぜひテイクアウェイでフラットホワイトを。

title: Carhartt WIP King’s Cross
excerpt: Carhartt was created over 125 years ago by a chap named Hamilton Carhartt on the notion of doing ‘the just and honest thing’. Fast forward …
content:
Carhartt was created over 125 years ago by a chap named Hamilton Carhartt on the notion of doing ‘the just and honest thing’. Fast forward 125 years and Carhartt WIP, a modernised Euro-branch to the original, has become an international pillar of iconic streetwear, featuring flagship stores in most European fashion capitals.

The London concept store, based in the bustling Kings Cross Pancras Square development, is a beautifully designed space by London-based design studio Faye Toogood that divides its attention between a clothing store and a dedicated espresso bar. Designed with a ‘rugged utilitarianism’ vibe in mind, it is the go to Carhartt WIP location for collaborative and special products, available only at King’s Cross.

Grab a quick pastry and flat white on your way to Kings Cross station or sip on an espresso while you’re shopping for a new pair of overalls. If you’re wondering when is best to pay a visit, Wednesday is always a safe bet – they do free coffee from 8-12 every week!

title: Temple
excerpt: Temple in Bude was created by Will, Keda and Conrad through their love of food, hospitality and fashion. Will brings the food component, having cut …
content:
Temple in Bude was created by Will, Keda and Conrad through their love of food, hospitality and fashion.

Will brings the food component, having cut his teeth in New Zealand where he reared and butchered his own livestock, caught fish, grew seasonal vegetables and baked bread daily. Afterwards, he moved to London to continue his passion. He worked in independent restaurants before moving down to the West Country to start the honest and delicious catering company Beautiful and the Feast, and later Temple with partner Keda.

Keda is born and bred in Bude, but after adventuring around the world (including long stints in New Zealand), she found herself in London project managing an extensive range of events, from intimate suppers to eight week long parties with 50,000 guests. With more than 15 years of hospitality experience around the world, it’s safe to say Keda knows how to look after guests.

Finally enter Conrad, the man behind the fashion component of the Temple equation. Conrad has owned fashion agencies and consultancy companies in London, so knows a thing or two about the latest threads.

The mix of these components and sincere dedication to quality has led to Temple, which is something quite special in its own right. The food is delicious (especially the salt beef), the coffee is bang on and the well curated selection of clothing keeps everything fresh and interesting.

title: Enzo’s on the Beach
excerpt: Literally… on, the, beach!
content:
Enjoy your breakfast, lunch, dinner, cocktails or coffee with your toes a couple of steps away from white sand and a bright blue bay. (We completely understand if you need to stop reading and book the next flight…)

Hervey Bay is on the Fraser Coast of sunny Queensland, Australia. With flights arriving daily from both Brisbane and Sydney, it’s an easy spot to visit for a long weekend. Alternatively, take the scenic route on wheels as it is also a three hour drive north of Brisbane. Pack your snorkel for exploring the Great Barrier Reef, sunscreen for protection from the North Australia sunshine and of course ensure an empty belly for continuous feasting at Enzo’s.

Named after the owner and operator, Enzo moved to Melbourne from Hanover in Germany after over a decade working in the sound and lighting department for big-name music gigs. Our hot tip is to name drop Tina Turner or Bon Jovi and he’ll have a story or two to tell.

He started in Hervey Bay as a tour guide for German tourists before claiming Enzo’s on the Beach in 2004. It was then more of a beach shack style café than the impressive, bay-side restaurant it is now after its rebuild earlier this year.

The breakfast menu includes all of the holiday favourites – eggs in every imaginable way, fresh fruit, plates full of protein and a good old-fashioned pancake stack.

See you there soon, hey?

subtitle: 最高の食事と最高のコーヒーで一日を華やかに彩りたい、それがLatte Graphicの想いです。
two_col_content:
彼らはとてもパワフルで献身的、そのエネルギーは独自のトレーニング体制にも大きく反映されています。そして今回、これまで町田と海老名で培ってきた知識をもとに最高のカフェが自由が丘にできました。

明るく開放感のあるスペースが私たちをとても心地よくそしてエネルギーで満たしてくれるような、そんな気持ちにさえなります。オセアニアスタイルのメニューはどれも彩り鮮やか。

オーストラリアの定番とも言えるビッグブレイクファストからアサイーボウルまであります。最高のコーヒーも忘れずに。中でもこのコーヒーアイスキューブ入りのコールドブリューは一日10杯までの限定。最高の食事と最高のコーヒーで一日を華やかに彩りたい、それがLatte Graphicの想いです。
title: Latte Graphic Jiyugaoka
excerpt: 最高の食事と最高のコーヒーで一日を華やかに彩りたい、それがLatte Graphicの想いです。
content:
“Through our coffee we share special moments, through our cafes we create memorable days, through our café culture we enrich peoples lives.” This is the Latte Graphic philosophy and their third rendition in the vibrant Jiyugaoka neighbourhood does not disappoint. Latte Graphic was our first customer in Japan and we have gotten to know them pretty well over the past few years. They are one of the most passionate and dedicated groups of people we have ever worked with and this energy is reflected in everything they do. Jiyugaoka is a powerhouse of a café representing a culmination of their collective knowledge gained over the last five years running multiple cafes in Machida. They were first inspired to open cafés by the Melbourne coffee scene but far from creating clones, each Latte Graphic destination has its own unique flavour.

The space is bright and breezy and the environment lends itself to lingering a little longer than is necessary to finish one of their epic breakfasts, whether it is the full Aussie or for the more health conscious an acai bowl.

It would be negligent to write about Latte Graphic without mentioning the coffee. This is the self-proclaimed foundation of their business. The coffee is genuinely exceptional although we can’t take all the credit. The gang at Latte Graphic provide an extensive 9 tiered training plan for their staff so needless to say there are no off days.

subtitle: お店のシンボルはワライカワセミ。オーストラリアを旅したことがあればきっと一度はあの笑い声のような鳴き声を聞いたことがあるはず。
more_content:
After living in Australia for seven years the owner Akaishi san fell in love with the café culture there and wanted to introduce the taste of Australia to Yokohama.

Good on You coffee stand is just a stone’s throw from Isezaki-chojamachi station. A big window opens onto the street with a simple sign above that sums it up in true Australian style – ‘Pie and Coffee’

Akaishi-san has perfected and possibly improved on the quintessentially Australian meat pie. They are making them from scratch in the café and we can vouch for the fact that they are authentic and delicious and the coffee is just as good.

After 5 pm the café transforms into a standing bar. Beer and whisky with chips anyone? Akaishi-san knows a thing or two about food and drinks pairing.

The cafe is thoughtfully designed with unpretentious details that make it a perfect neighbourhood hangout. This in combination with the warm welcome makes you feel like an instant regular.
title: Good On You Coffee Stand
excerpt: オーストラリアのカフェをそのまま持ってきたような、そんなコーヒースタンドが横浜にできました。
content:
Good on Youの名物はまさにローカルのカフェにありそうなミートパイ。オーナーの赤石さんと奥様がカフェで手作りしています。最近はアップルパイもはじめました。コーヒーやパイのテイクアウトができる大きな窓は道行く人の足を止めます。夏にはお祭りがあって屋台で賑わうそうです。パイも名物になっちゃうかも。

サンドイッチとパスタもコーヒーと一緒にテイクアウトして、近くの公園でランチはどう？夕方からはビールやウイスキー、チップスと合わせて一杯どう？肩の力を抜いて、気軽に寄れるそんなスポットがここにあります。初めて行ってもリラックスできるのはきっとお二人の明るいおもてなしのおかげ。

subtitle: "このカフェはオーナーの好きなものをかき集めた感じ"
more_content:
If you didn’t know it was there you might walk right past Espresso D works without enjoying one of the best coffees and spots to take a breather from the hustle and bustle of Ebisu.

Inside is an eclectic mix of the proprietor’s favourite things. A sea of exposed bulbs, hints of old-world grandeur alongside quirky features including a coffee bean sculpture comprised of 25,000 beans. The glossy black la Marzocco takes pride of place on the marble benchtop and if you are lucky Maho will be standing behind it ready to make you a delicious brew.

Brunch is a must and the ricotta pancakes should not be missed.
title: Espresso D Works Ebisu
excerpt: 壁一面に敷き詰められた25万ものコーヒー豆でできたウォールアートや、本棚のような隠し扉がおもしろい。
content:
壁一面に敷き詰められた25万ものコーヒー豆でできたウォールアートや本棚のような隠し扉がおもしろい。はだか電球のライトが大きなテーブルを照らしてそこはバーのような雰囲気、だけどカウチやランプがあってどこか暖かくて居心地のよい空間。

ボリュームたっぷりのコブサラダ、ガパオライスやリコッタパンケーキなど豊富なフードメニューが揃っています。週末のブランチには最高のコーヒーも忘れずに。夜はタパスをつまみながらクラフトビールやサングリアが楽しめます。

エスプレッソマシンが座る大理石のような大きなベンチ、そこに積んであるのはユニークな迷彩柄のテイクアウトカップ。”このカフェはオーナーの好きなものをかき集めた感じ” と話すのはバリスタのまほさん。恵比寿へ行ったらD worksに寄ってみてください。最高のコーヒーと彼女の笑顔が迎えてくれます。

subtitle: 鎌倉で特にユニークで最高においしいコーヒーが飲めるのがここ。
more_content:
The journey to Casa Kamakura is just as charming as the destination. It is one of the stops on the Enoden line, a nostalgic railway that links Fujisawa to Kamakura. Casa Kamakura Espresso is tucked away in a quiet alley in Hase brewing the best coffee in town. The owner Sugawara-san is an architect and he opened the café in early 2016 to create a design community when he relocated his architecture practice Double Doors (next door) to Kamakura.

At first, the space blends seamlessly with the quaint surroundings but on closer inspection, you will discover some curious features including Sugawara-sans penchant for vintage Macintosh products, the older the better. Some of the new uses include an aquarium for their pet fish and a wine dispenser of course.

The origins of the name ‘Casa’ along with the philosophy are Spanish. Sugawara-san wanted to recreate the relaxed and social atmosphere experienced in Spanish bars that make you feel like you are eating and drinking in a friends living room. Ingredients sourced from the local farmers market and the beer and wine that flows in Summer add to this sense.

If you still need an excuse to visit, hydrangea season strikes at the same time that the skies open up for the entire month of June. This native flora is celebrated with a similar zeal to the cherry blossoms and the location of Casa Kamakura is a hydrangea hotbed attracting thousands of visitors every rainy season. We recommend you pick up a coffee and brolly to go and enjoy the purple haze or if you are that way inclined we hear the surf is pretty good too.

location.address: 〒248-0016 １９, 1 Chome-14 Hase, Kamakura, Kanagawa Prefecture 248-0016, Japan

title: Casa Kamakura Espresso
excerpt: 鎌倉から江ノ電に乗って。
content:
建築士であるオーナーの菅原さんがオフィスの引越しを機にそのお隣ではじめたカフェ。iki Espressoで飲んだエスプレッソのおいしさに一目惚れしたのも同じ時期でした。

Allpressを代表するKiba Blendをエスプレッソでどうぞ。また種子島のしょうがジャムを使ったジンジャーエールや、近くのファーマーズマーケットで仕入れた野菜を使ったデリ・スコーンも人気。名前の由来Casaはスペイン語で“家”。菅原さんのカフェがお客さんとの会話のきっかけになればという思いもあり、その空間はまさに友達の家のよう。またバル文化もアイデアのひとつ。ビールもあります、この夏ワインもはじめるそうです。

鎌倉へあじさいを見に行ったらぜひテイクアウトで街を歩いてみてください。ビーチの帰りにおいしいエスプレッソを飲みながら過ごす朝はいかがでしょう。ちなみに菅原さんは昔のアップルファンで、マッキントッシュを水槽やミュージックプレイヤーに改造しちゃうんです。ちょっと気になるものたちがあちらこちらにあります。

subtitle: Situated on a beautiful corner in Fitzrovia, Jova London is a café and office space all in one. Armen and Vanessa opened Jova London with the goal to create modern day work-life convenience. The convenience of quality coffee and healthy food in a cosy surrounding to provide the right setting for a productive day’s work.
title: Jova London
excerpt: Situated on a beautiful corner in Fitzrovia, Jova London is a café and office space all in one.
content:
Off Charlotte Street you walk into Jova where you can enjoy a Redchurch blend along with an item off the nutritious seasonal menu that will keep you energised for a busy day ahead. Downstairs is the shared working space where you can host a conference call, meet work colleagues or simply knuckle down at a work station all in a first class and dedicated working environment.

Whether you’re after a change of scenery from the office, need a peaceful place to hold a meeting or after a spot on cup of coffee then go visit the team at Jova London.

location.address: 15-16 Triton St, Kings Cross, London NW1 3BF

subtitle: There is no denying Bambina Ponsonby is a community institution. But for some of their customers, Bambina has gone beyond just a cafe and is lovingly referred to as their second home – but after being open for 20 years, no one should be surprised.
title: Bambina Ponsonby
excerpt: Sarah and Pete, owner-operators, are locals themselves having lived in Ponsonby for 27 years now and can safely say the diverse community that surrounds Bambina …
content:
Sarah and Pete, owner-operators, are locals themselves having lived in Ponsonby for 27 years now and can safely say the diverse community that surrounds Bambina Ponsonby isn’t as flashy as it appears.

One of the longtime favourites is the Salmon Salad – packed with ginger, lots of greens, limes & herbs. Sarah says it’s one of those dishes that, once you’re finished devouring it, feels like your whole body is thanking you. The salad is crisp, the grilled salmon fillet melts in your mouth and the warm dressing has a fresh zing to it with kaffir lime & chilli.

Only a year ago, Bambina underwent a brand new fit out with interior designer Katie Lockhart – who Sarah says creates spaces “that you just want to fall into and stick around or maybe never leave”. The brief was to create a space that still felt like Bambina, not just some new café in their space.

Our relationship with Sarah & Pete is something special too – we have been supplying their coffee since day one and our Ponsonby Espresso Bar sits on the original Bambina site. Being next door neighbours works out perfectly for both of us – some customers often feel like the two places are one, which just shows how well we sit next to each other. Sarah will often find herself running a breakfast salad through to an Allpress customer next door or if we have someone who feels like a full meal, we’ll send them Bambinas way.

A match made in Ponsonby Road heaven.

title: Albion Canteen
excerpt: With an emphasis on whole foods, Albion Canteen is the perfect place to grab a pick-me-up and a bite to eat in Napier.
content:
Albion Canteen is located in the middle of Napier’s busy business and shopping centre and offers a unique eating experience based on fresh daily salads and good quality cabinet food such as made to order sandwiches and savoury dishes, and also a range of delicious fresh pressed juices.

Albion focuses on food options that can be eaten every day: healthy, fast, delicious and nutritious and with an emphasis on whole foods.

Their light and bright dining area and space outside for dining alfresco and the perfect nook for some people-watching. In the weekends Albion is the perfect meeting place for those on holiday or as a base for shopping sprees.

title: Hermann’s Berlin
excerpt: Based on Torstrasse in the heart of Mitte, Hermann’s Berlin ain’t your usual café. Of course you’ll find all the classics including healthy sandwiches, muffins, …
content:
Based on Torstrasse in the heart of Mitte, Hermann’s Berlin ain’t your usual café. Of course you’ll find all the classics including healthy sandwiches, muffins, salads and delicious coffee. However if you dig a little deeper you’ll notice the space is geared towards food education, experimentation and innovation.

The goal at Hermann’s (named after famous entrepreneur Hermann Bahlsen) is to research, test and innovate to discover delicious food for future generations, all whilst providing a relaxing environment to work, meet and learn a thing or two about food sustainability.

Bring your dog along and enjoy a Redchurch blend at this beautifully designed all day café.

location.address: Unit 63B Wood Green Shopping Cit, 169 High Road, London N22 6BA

title: Castello Coffee Company – Bruntsfield Links
excerpt: Castello in Bruntsfield Links is the second of the two sites owned by Sandro del Greco – Scottish coffee extraordinaire. Like the original, the second …
content:
Castello in Bruntsfield Links is the second of the two sites owned by Sandro del Greco – Scottish coffee extraordinaire. Like the original, the second café makes the most of a prominent Edinburgh landmark, well known by locals and tourists alike.

Castello Bruntsfield Links opened five years after the original, just in time for the summer sun of 2017. It makes the most of its enviable position near the busy commuter route of Bruntsfield Place, as much as its proximity on the edge of Bruntsfield Links. The Links are renowned as a place to visit for a for a round of golf, and connect to the Meadows, Edinburgh’s go-to spot for tanning, frisbee, picnics and other shenanigans.

Sandro’s 3-Group La Marzocco Strada takes pride of place in the window of the café, looking out for all to see. The food at Castello is as exceptional as the coffee that Sandro and his team pride themselves on. It’s the perfect place for some time out, or for a take-away coffee on your way to work. Better still, grab some caffeinated goodness on your way to enjoy some sunshine on the Links or in the Meadows.

title: Beanz Cafe
excerpt: A few drinks and a New Years resolutions between friends…
content:
Based in the picturesque town of Pau, Beanz café is serving up a slice of Australian and New Zealand flavour in the southern reaches of France.

The café idea came about after a couple of drinks between friends which spiralled into New Year’s resolutions, and soon enough turned into the real deal. Lauren, Ben, Colin and Emma were all familiar with Allpress being from Australia and New Zealand, so it was a no brainer to team up and serve Redchurch Blend in Southern France.

Lauren and Emma run the café – which has a nice mix of New Zealand and Australian expats (a solid Rugby community in Pau) along with locals keen for a great cup of coffee.

Beanz is situated on Impasse La Foi, a cosy side street off the busy main drag- a perfect spot for a coffee and a piece of cake.

subtitle: Nestled in the handy location of Fresh Choice City Market in central Christchurch, Lil’Ruby is no ordinary supermarket-site cafe. In fact, it’s pretty extraordinary.
title: Lil Ruby
excerpt: Lil’Ruby is no ordinary supermarket-site cafe. In fact, it’s pretty extraordinary.
content:
With a delicious range of salads, snacks and sweets in the cabinet, an impressive array of juices and sodas in the chiller and a stunning white La Marzocco coffee machine at centre stage pumping out Allpress coffees, it’s no wonder Lil’ Ruby is bustling with more than just hangry grocery shoppers* taking a breather.

Small in size but beautiful in its offering and its appearance – white tiles, open wooden shelving and a cool red logo – Lil’ Ruby is just as the name suggests: a little gem. It’s open 7 am – 4 pm daily, and whether you’re a short black and paleo cookie kind of soul or more of a flat white and salted caramel doughnut enthusiast, Lil’ Ruby Espresso has you covered. They’ve also got a great range of salads and sandwiches to take away on your lunch break or enjoy at the bench seats whilst watching the world go by.

The staff at Lil’Ruby are a real testament to the values of the establishment too – they’re friendly, approachable and at the ready to help whatever your craving — which, looking at the cabinet, might just be one of each and a large coffee, thank you.

*And nice ones, too.

subtitle: Our latest flagship, situated in Woolloongabba. More than just a café, our home in Brisbane is here to support our local café customers, to welcome our community and for our coffee drinkers to pick up a delicious brew. We can't wait to meet you, Brisbane.
title: Brisbane Cafe

subtitle: Brunch or lunch out is always a treat, but don’t you sometimes just crave enjoying that delicious experience in a more relaxed, homely environment?
title: Hartnell’s Cafe and Bar
excerpt: Between its stunning spaces, delicious food and friendly staff, it feels just like home.
content:
Christchurch’s Hartnells Cafe & Bar is the perfect answer to this. Nestled in the suburb of Prebbleton, Hartnells is situated in a beautifully refurbished old villa which a century ago housed the much loved Hartnells Butchery.

Between its stunning spaces, delicious food and friendly staff, it feels just like home.

Brimming with locals – both as staff members and as customers – Hartnells has a strong sense of community and family, heightening its homely charm and making it well worth a visit next time you’re in the Garden City.

Open daily with a menu spanning breakfast, lunch, bar snacks, cabinet food, drinks and coffees, it’s a home you’ll never want to leave. For breakfast Hartnells offers perfectly executed favourites like french toast, ‘John’s Benny’ eggs benedict and smashed avo as well as some tasty and more adventurous dishes such as vegan spiced lentils and the ‘Hartnell’s Hearty Breaky’ with everything from homemade baked beans to charred red onion and merguez sausage. On the lunch and tapas side of things, Hartnells spoils visitors for choice with their ‘Cast and Catch’ beer battered fish and chips, nachos, caesar salad, prawn and pineapple skewers —the list goes on. There’s even a ‘Juniors All Day menu’ which we are hoping is open to seniors too, as the Banana & Nutella Toastie sounds like our cup of tea. Food can be enjoyed in the light and bright inside space or outside on tables in the beautiful rose-lined gardens.

location.address: Gisborne Village Shopping Centre, Shop 13, 22 Brantome St, Gisbourne, VIC 3437

subtitle: A stone’s throw away from its big sister, Greenhaus Coffee can be found in the growing, buzzing area of Teneriffe in Brisbane city. And with a big sister like Botanica Real Food (@botanicarealfood), it’s worth going to the top of your list next time you’re seeking coffee in the area.
title: Greenhaus Coffee
excerpt: A stone’s throw away from its big sister, Greenhaus Coffee can be found in the growing, buzzing area of Teneriffe in Brisbane city.
content:
From 6am every day you can drop-in to grab breakfast and coffee on the go. Everything from tartines to breakfast parfait to baked treats, it’s all delicious and baked fresh each morning in the Botanica kitchen two doors down.

Notable mentions include the inviting doorstep greeting of rise and shine and while it’s a favourite of all the local people, it’s a favourite of all the cutest doggos in town too!

title: Phlox Books
excerpt: Aimée Madill knew she wanted to open her own bookshop before she turned 30, so when she spotted a DIY store closing down three minutes from her house in Leyton, she knew this was the one.
content:
Aimée Madill knew she wanted to open her own bookshop before she turned 30, so when she spotted a DIY store closing down three minutes from her house in Leyton, she knew this was the one.

Phlox books, named after Aimée’s parents’ 1980’s design store in Belfast, has quickly become a celebrated haven on the recently pedestrianised Francis Road in Leyton. Phlox provides a beautifully cosy space for Mum’s and bubs to have a quiet coffee, or for other literary enthusiasts to enjoy a Beavertown beer (depending on time of day). Regardless, the underlying theme is great literature – and trust us, Aimée knows a good book. After completing a masters in English Literature, Aimée has worked in independent bookshops in Ireland, London and Paris before running out of space in her own library and subsequently realising her dream of creating Phlox.

To top it off, the resident French bulldog Huxley is usually kicking around the store – so what’s better than a delicious coffee, a good book and a French bulldog?

subtitle: Take a look inside the McTavish showroom and store, also serving as the perfect post-surf destination for a great coffee.

title: McTavish Surf
excerpt: Located in the Arts & Industry Estate, our Byron Bay neighbours McTavish Surfboards now have a showroom, cafe, world-class factory, creative offices and event space …
content:
Located in the Arts & Industry Estate, our Byron Bay neighbours McTavish Surfboards now have a showroom, cafe, world-class factory, creative offices and event space all under one roof. The welcoming space is just as conducive to a quick early morning caffeine stop, as it is to lingering, claiming a sunny seat beneath the pandanus and inevitably running into a friend.

Whether you’re a beginner or regular surfer, each of the McTavish staff surf (most faces spotted in the showroom or behind the coffee machine are the brands’ team of ambassadors) and they love nothing more than to share their experience and stoke. Visitors might also be lucky enough to head on a guided tour through the factory, where you begin to understand the amazing process and complex craftsmanship that goes into creating each of the boards you see on show, in the adjacent space.

Brimming with custom furniture, finishes and bespoke design by a veritable hit list of local craftsmen and women, alongside the complete quiver of masterfully designed surfboards (and more recently, apparel) – the new McTavish HQ epitomises the company’s long-standing philosophy ‘Dedicated to the Craft’.

title: Trove
excerpt: What started in 2011 as a small market stand selling jam and chutney, Marcus and Katy have slowly but surely grown into the beauty TROVE …
content:
What started in 2011 as a small market stand selling jam and chutney, Marcus and Katy have slowly but surely grown into the beauty TROVE is today.

It’s quite easy to stroll past their café on the main drag of Levenshulme, but we assure you this would be a big mistake. Once you walk in you are greeted with fantastic northern hospitality and the smell of local magic cooked up in the consistently bustling kitchen.

Everything you eat in TROVE has been made by the team, from the sourdough (TROVE actually also run a pretty slick wholesale bakery) to their brown sauce and all the delicious cakes on the counter.

Marcus and Katy have created something pretty special with TROVE- it’s definitely worth searching out.

subtitle: At a time where new cafes and eateries seem to be popping up more frequently than flash-lit iPhones at a Beyonce concert, it can be hard to know who has the ‘x’ factor and who doesn’t. But as far as Christchurch’s Grain Coffee + Eatery is concerned, the x, y and the z factor are covered.
title: Grain Coffee and Eatery
excerpt: At a time where new cafes and eateries seem to be popping up more frequently than flash-lit iPhones at a Beyonce concert, it can be hard to know who has the ‘x’ factor and who doesn’t.
content:
Housed in an otherwise unmemorable street in central Christchurch in what was formerly the Fort Rubber Moulding factory, Grain is an extremely memorable spot. The space itself is beautiful – simple, industrial, bright and nearly all white except for pops of beautiful wood and a very seductive olive green coffee machine atop the counter.

Grain opens its doors between 7:30am – 4pm on weekdays and 8am – 1pm on Saturdays, providing a relaxed, friendly environment with an irresistible cabinet selection (Date, Caramel and Cinnamon roll, anyone?) and an impressive seasonal menu which changes on a weekly basis depending on what’s fresh and what’s good at the time. And if their Warm Vegan Grain Bowl with grains, marinated tempeh, edamame, cucumber, chipotle cashew aioli and miso dressing is anything to go by, it’s all good, no matter what the time of year. The toasted banana bread with fresh banana, toffee sauce, dark chocolate, coconut yoghurt and crushed almonds is probably quite a good indication, too.

Alongside their inviting food menu, there are some delicious smoothies, cold pressed Green Roots organic juices and Karma Cola fizzy drinks. And as for coffee, you’ll be in good hands with our Supremo Blend — as per.

The only concern with Grain Coffee + Eatery, is that once you’ve visited, you might find you’ve set the bar for future eating, hydrating and caffeinating experiences a little too high.

A sign of the ‘x’ factor indeed.

subtitle: Milk Haus is a leap into the unknown.
title: Milk Haus
excerpt: Milk Haus is meant to be enjoyed at a slower pace of life – a true labour of love, and one we hope you enjoy.
content:
Situated on the outskirts of Milton, in what was once a 19th Century Cheese Factory, is Milk Haus – a wholefoods cafe worth visiting.

Thier philosophy is about good, delicious, local food – going back to the basics. They may not be certified ‘organic’, but they farm all of their produce the way nature intended – no toxins, preservatives or anything artificial.

For anything above and beyond what they can’t grow, they partner with other like-minded locals – fishermen, farmers, artisans & home gardeners.

Milk Haus is meant to be enjoyed at a slower pace of life – a true labour of love, and one we hope you enjoy.

subtitle: Hidden in an area that is known for its darker, grungier interiors Lokal + Co is a hidden gem in West End, Brisbane.
title: Lokal + Co
excerpt: Hidden in an area that is known for its darker, grungier interiors Lokal + Co is a hidden gem in West End, Brisbane.
content:
Lokal + Co is a neighbourhood eatery and bar with a strong Nordic influence, serving modern seasonal plates crafted from local produce. Owner-operator Helge Olsen swears by the Potato waffles with house-cured gravalax – and the customers agree.

Other favourites on the extensive menu include the Avocado bowl, mizuna leaves, zucchini salad and feta, or if after something a bit sweeter – the banana fritters rolled in cinnamon sugar, crème fraiche, papaya lime salad and peanut brittle.

Don’t miss out on this next time you’re in Queensland – you’ll regret it.

location.address: Shop 1/240 Little Collins Street, Melbourne VIC 3000

title: Kitty Burns
excerpt: Serving food until 3.30pm seven days a week, Kitty Burns’ diverse and delicious menu could keep you very content if you were to dine each …
content:
Serving food until 3.30pm seven days a week, Kitty Burns’ diverse and delicious menu could keep you very content if you were to dine each and every day.

The menu hosts some delicious twists on the usual suspects – Eggs Burndict for example, which includes braised rolled pork neck, jalapeño hollandaise, crispy pig ear, apple salad and poached eggs. And French Toast is nothing to be taken lightly here, either – lime curd, vanilla ganache, orange-honey whip, anyone? The Popcorn Chilli Chicken + Waffles might just tickle your fancy, too.

excerpt: Wander up from Currumbin’s beach and you’ll find a haven of organic, raw goodness. The Salt Mill serves delicious juices, smoothies, acai bowls and a …
content:
Wander up from Currumbin’s beach and you’ll find a haven of organic, raw goodness. The Salt Mill serves delicious juices, smoothies, acai bowls and a small range of organic wholefood snacks in a rustic little space where regulars and visitors can’t help but flock.

On the coffee front, a different Allpress single origin is on offer each week, as well as Allpress espresso options.

title: Waxed
excerpt: Tucked away just off the main drag of Hossegor, you’ll find the guys in a cosy corner perfect for grabbing a drink and snack in a sunny spot with the latest surf mag.
content:
Waxed is the dream that became reality for two lifelong friends that set out to provide a modern experience of coffee culture in the popular surf town of Hossegor.

Will and Cai started Waxed in 2016 and have been offering up Allpress coffee, locally sourced fresh food and a place to hang for the locals and influx of surf seekers ever since. Tucked away just off the main drag of Hossegor, you’ll find the guys in a cosy corner perfect for grabbing a drink and snack in a sunny spot with the latest surf mag.

If you’re on the search for a top-notch coffee and a healthy brekkie (the Shakshuka and Berry Super Granola are incredible), then go visit Will, Cai and the team at Waxed – they’ll sort you out.

title: The Bach Broadway Market
excerpt: The Bach is named after the small, often modest holiday home– pronounced ‘batch’– where New Zealanders go to unwind. Nikki and her partner, Zuzie, aim …
content:
The Bach is named after the small, often modest holiday home– pronounced ‘batch’– where New Zealanders go to unwind.

Nikki and her partner, Zuzie, aim to bring a little taste of Kiwi hospitality and fun to east London and, even without the sandy shores, people are flocking to their two shops for those tranquil vibes.

The Bach isn’t their first venture into the world of corn fritters and flat whites. They are seasoned pros, having previously set up and run a buzzing café in Shoreditch called Long White Cloud after English translation of the Maori name for New Zealand, Aotearoa. They like to keep it close to their roots.

They believe that ‘happy food tastes good’ and are strong advocates of sourcing organic, sustainable and seasonal products. That mantra translates into delicious food, made from scratch that caters for gluten, wheat and dairy free diets as well. Happy food, indeed.

Head downstairs and you’ll find a shared workspace where you can sip on a Redchurch Blend flattie in between meetings. Artist collaborations and exhibitions are also welcomed; their walls are covered with local talent.

title: The Hub
excerpt: Along the Great North Road from London to Scotland and on route out to the Chilterns you will find this cosy café, ‘The Hub’.  In …
content:
Along the Great North Road from London to Scotland and on route out to the Chilterns you will find this cosy café, ‘The Hub’.  In an 1800’s building on the high street, this is the perfect refuel spot for cyclists and walkers alike. Simon and Lindy grabbed what they could from their own home to make the space as warm and comforting as possible, and stacks of books and memorabilia pay homage to Simon’s deep passion for all things cycling.

If you find yourself in Redbourne with a puncture, never fear. Drop your bike into their repair shop, The Bike Loft, down the road and head to The Hub for a coffee and a bite.

The menu is small and simple with homemade cakes to die for. They also have a few options for a light lunch, whether it be soup or a mouth-watering cheese toastie.

Most of their ingredients are sourced in Redbourn. They use bread from Redbournbury Mill and veggies grown and delivered by Graham, who makes a delicious courgette cake.

title: The Groundworks
excerpt: Ben and Tom founded The Groundworks in early 2014 with a simple mission statement: to provide the best food and coffee in Hertfordshire. When we …
content:
Ben and Tom founded The Groundworks in early 2014 with a simple mission statement: to provide the best food and coffee in Hertfordshire.

When we met the childhood mates they were both just 23 and had just taken on a greasy spoon in what they refer to as their unicorn – a stunning 16th-century shop with an alcohol license. Not everyone would be able to spot the potential in this gem of a site but we are glad they did.

The boys transformed the old shop into a truly beautiful space and now have a thriving business providing breakfast, lunch and a killer Sunday brunch to local residents and have built a solid reputation for great service and innovative products.

With a train journey out of King’s Cross shorter than most tube journeys and a breakfast experience that rivals the best of the capital, The Groundworks should be on your weekend hit-list.

title: Shot Espresso
excerpt: An independent coffee shop, deli and apéritif bar started by friends of Italian, Australian and English extraction.
content:
For a little shop, Shot does it all. A deli, cafe & aperitif bar rolled into one for an all-day adventure through simple, delicious living. John, Davide and Mike opened Shot in to make what they love – first class coffee, light bites, deli treats, seriously good wine & cocktails and more – served up in the heart of buzzing Fulham.

“At Shot we’re all about quality, simplicity and freshness. We use only the finest natural ingredients, as much of our produce as possible is organic and we love to work with small, family-run producers. You can only get the best out if you put the best in…”

title: Estate Office Coffee
excerpt: Trust us when we say you’ll want this to be your local.
content:
Estate Office Coffee is small, simple and perfectly formed with The Redchurch Blend and locally made cakes taking centre stage.  A few stools placed around the bar give punters an opportunity to rest their legs, but most stay for the cosy vibes and friendly chat.

Joe, an amateur coffee geek and Redchurch Street regular and Clarke, a hospo veteran teamed up after meeting in their local café.  Joe’s experience as a property developer helped him find the perfect site with a wealth of history and character. Built in 1906 as an Estate Office for nearby flats, the building has housed various businesses. During the second world war, it was home to Streatham Comforts Fund (a name they toyed with reusing) for distributing goods to soldiers.

The interiors are just as charming as the building itself, with the counter made of reclaimed Iroko wood from school science labs and the menu board a rescued and lovingly restored museum display case.

subtitle: Simple, tasty & fresh... like a Highland breeze wafting up your kilt (and before you ask, those are their words, not ours!)
title: Deeney’s Cafe
excerpt: Deeney’s started as a street food stall back in the summer of 2012 and they’ve been bringing a taste of Scotland to Londoners ever since. …
content:
Deeney’s started as a street food stall back in the summer of 2012 and they’ve been bringing a taste of Scotland to Londoners ever since. For Carol (Deeney), the hospo business is in her blood – growing up working in her parents Scottish Café, she has spent her life cooking food for the people around her. When she’d finally had enough of the 9-5 lifestyle, she decided to chuck it all in and go back to doing what she loves.

After a few years of building up a reputation at some of London’s most celebrated food markets (including a regular stint at Broadway Market which they still have), Carol and her partner Paddy opened their first permanent home in Leyton. The cosy 20-seater café was a welcome addition to the neighbourhood where good coffee was still pretty hard to find.

Keeping in the spirit of entrepreneurship Carol, Paddy and the team rolled up their sleeves to whip the café into shape just 6 weeks after getting the keys. After spending long nights painting and sanding, their new home was finally transformed from a French Tearoom to the Leyton institution it is now.

Their famous ‘Macbeth’ haggis toastie has a cult following of its own (we’re talkin’ oozing cheddar cheese, caramelised onions, mustard and of course a thick slab of Haggis) and vegetarians fear not, the Lady Macbeth is just as indulgent.

Phrases such as ‘life changer’ and ‘London’s best cheese toastie’ are often thrown around when Deeney’s is mentioned but don’t just take our word for it, pay them and grab a Macbeth of your own.

title: Mala Kaffe
excerpt: It was perfect timing for Carey and husband Johan to make the move to Margate a few years back. The small sea town in Kent …
content:
It was perfect timing for Carey and husband Johan to make the move to Margate a few years back. The small sea town in Kent is growing in population, restaurants and cafe’s by the minute.

Mala Kaffe brings a taste of Swedish fika culture to Margate’s Harbour Arms. This hole-in-the-wall cafe features painted brick with a shrine of old school hand grinders on the wall, and loads of greenery.

Inside is small, but don’t let that put you off. There are a scattering of chairs and tables outside for you to enjoy the sea view, in the winter they make sure you’re snug with a hot water bottle and blanket.

The menu is simple and delicious featuring a house pickled Herring Platter, salmon on rye, open sandwiches, gravlax and granola. Make sure you leave room for desert because their cakes are to die for, and there’s a lot to choose from.

title: Laneway & Co.
excerpt: Laneway and Co. was born after Nick, owner and operator, decided to start a café in his own hometown after learning the coffee trade in …
content:
Laneway and Co. was born after Nick, owner and operator, decided to start a café in his own hometown after learning the coffee trade in Melbourne working with a fellow Allpress customer.

Situated in the heart of Newcastle just a short stroll from the train station, Laneway and Co. is a clean and sleek café that does an exceptional job with your daily coffee. It’s also important to note Nick does a damn good ham, cheese and mustard toastie – the crisps on the side are always an added bonus!

In just over a year, through hard work and dedication to making a fantastic coffee, Nick has turned Laneway and Co. into a Newcastle institution, and now has another café up the road in Jesmond. He’s there every day so be sure to pop in and say hi.

title: Bloomsbury Coffee House
excerpt: Coffee, bakes and thoughtfully sourced homemade food are the focus of this hidden gem in the heart of Holborn. Bloomsbury Coffee House is a basement …
content:
Coffee, bakes and thoughtfully sourced homemade food are the focus of this hidden gem in the heart of Holborn. Bloomsbury Coffee House is a basement café which is easy to miss – but is definitely worth keeping an eye out for.

Dream team Hannah and Karl put a lot of love into the space, which is reflected in their loyal following of workers and students from nearby offices and universities alike. Tourists staying at the hotel above make the café their home away from home and soak up the welcoming vibes in an area which is otherwise flooded with franchises.

The site was originally the breakfast rooms of their family run B & B called St Athans Hotel. Over 6 years ago, Hannah decided to leave her career in events for something rewarding of her own – the transformation of the space into a beautiful café.

It doesn’t hurt that Hannah has a degree in Culinary Arts – the cinnamon buns have their own cult following and are an integral part of the ever-changing menu, alongside colourful salads and hearty soups.  Karl describes his first ‘coffee epiphany’ after drinking a flat white at the Allpress Redchurch Street café and the rest as they say is history!

location.address: 11A Buckfast St, Bethnal Green, London E2 6EY

subtitle: A hive of activity most days of the week, it’s a popular spot for breakfast, a quiche and salad for lunch, or picking out a few cheeses, charcuterie and wine to take home.
more_content:
Stephane, the owner, has created a space that is very much a collection of what he loves, with cheeses from his home region of France and coffee cups he brought back in a suitcase from Puglia. Whatever you get at La Bouche you know it is tried and tested by Stephane himself. He is a strong believer in being a customer in his own cafe and making sure the results live up to the vision.

Not shy to take risks, he opened up in 2004 on a street that had many empty storefronts and was still relatively untouched by the coming wave of regeneration. He knew it was the right place and time to open because of the £200 boots on sale in the shop down the road. The boots seemed out of place for the area, but he admired the shop’s guts.

La Bouche’s lasting presence and popularity comes down to an ethos of honesty, boldness and friendship. And damn good products!
title: L’eau à la Bouche

excerpt: ‘We see our cafés as spaces for innovative, creative folk to develop and work ideas from’
content:
The Bach is named after the small, often modest holiday home– pronounced ‘batch’– where New Zealanders go to unwind.

Nikki and her partner, Zuzie, aim to bring a little taste of Kiwi hospitality and fun to east London and, even without the sandy shores, people are flocking to their two shops for those tranquil vibes.

The Bach isn’t their first venture into the world of corn fritters and flat whites. They are seasoned pros, having previously set up and ran a buzzing café in Shoreditch called Long White Cloud after the English translation of the Maori name for New Zealand, Aotearoa. They like to keep it close to their roots.

They believe that ‘happy food tastes good’ and are strong advocates of sourcing organic, sustainable and seasonal products. That mantra translates into delicious food, made from scratch that caters for gluten, wheat and dairy free diets as well. Happy food, indeed.

title: Violet
excerpt: Fresh off the plane from San Francisco circa 2005, Claire never imagined the small one-day-a-week stall she started on Broadway Market would evolve into one …
content:
Fresh off the plane from San Francisco circa 2005, Claire never imagined the small one-day-a-week stall she started on Broadway Market would evolve into one of London’s most celebrated artisan bakeries.

The Bakery itself holds a special presence nestled in the heart of Wilton way. Claire was inspired by the Prada Marfa installation in Texas, and has incorporated a minimalist but happy and welcoming feel into every aspect of the space itself. Talking about how she keeps Violet fresh and relevant, she mentions she never loses sight of why she started it in the first place. She simply wanted great cakes, great coffee and a place she would want to go herself. By keeping quality first and foremost, it’s safe to say she has well and truly exceeded her original goals.

When next in East London, Violets is well worth making a priority visit. A personal favourite of the Allpress Dalston team is the chocolate caramel rum cake with salted caramel butter cream – it’s a bit of a life changer.

title: Opera Kitchen
excerpt: Located in the original Power Board building, with its classic deco styling, Opera Kitchen holds true to its tagline: Hastings Raised.
content:
Opera Kitchen is proudly based centrally in Hastings and considered one of the city’s favourite eateries. Located in the original Power Board building, with its classic deco styling, Opera Kitchen holds true to its tagline: Hastings Raised. This speaks to local pride but also to Hastings’ people supporting the team since their establishment here ten years ago.

The café is a success in part because Hastings supports them, and also because they identify and utilise the importance of the quality ingredients raised here. Ingredients are sourced locally where-ever possible including fresh fruit and vegetables, eggs, meat, wines and beers.

Opera Kitchen focus on contemporary food featuring the best of Hawke’s Bay produce with an emphasis on seasonality; the menu changes with the seasons to reflect this. Alongside their cuisine, you can find local boutique wines and craft beers to match.

With a light, bright atmosphere they have the flexibility to create intimate spaces as well as cater for larger groups. You’ll also find Parlour Projects adjacent to Opera Kitchen – perfect for those who are after a bit of creative inspiration on the side of their lunch.

title: Bread, Espresso &
excerpt: Nestled in the sleepy seaside town of Thirroul, it’s the perfect beginning to your NSW South Coast road trip.
content:
Nestled in front of the escarpment, it’s the perfect spot to sit outdoors and enjoy breakfast in the sunshine. With an array of pastries, breads and other baked goods to choose from, it’s likely that you’ll want to both eat here and then grab some takeaway goodies for later.

If you’re wanting to spend the night in the area then look no further then next door to the café, where the owners have just opened up an Airbnb in a two bedroom weatherboard cottage. It’s pared-back with all the makings of a classic Australian beach house, plus, you’ll wake up here with both good coffee and the ocean on your doorstep.

content:
The team makes a wide range of chocolate treats on site, as well as sweet and savoury pastries, fresh salads and an incredible range of daily bread. They also celebrate seasonal changes with creative fillings and other seasonal offerings: perfect for Easter and Christmas delights!

Picnic is located in Ahuriri and is the perfect place to pick up a picnic and head for the beach, the boardwalk or one of Napier’s many beautiful parks. A must visit next time you are in the Bay.

title: Piknic Cafe
excerpt: A suburban neighbourhood café just a stone’s throw away from Castor Bay Beach.
content:
A suburban neighbourhood café just a stone’s throw away from Castor Bay Beach. This is a café for the local community nestled within a residential area, set slightly back off the main road. The décor is simple yet sophisticated, with enough space to enjoy a coffee in the sun or a place to sit in the shade when your fur baby needs a rest!

With the unusually shaped building splitting in two, it made sense to make create two spaces within Piknic – one part deli and espresso bar, the other a place to meet with friends and enjoy the experience of table service and a full menu. Homemade food includes an array of salads, perfectly poached eggs and a damn good choice of sweet treats.

The laid-back vibes make this the perfect place to stop in on your way to the beach, on your morning walk or for a leisurely bunch.

excerpt: Locally sourced, hand crafted and freshly made is Highland Merchants mantra. Don’t expect the same thing twice when you visit though – they offer a …
content:
Locally sourced, hand crafted and freshly made is Highland Merchants mantra. Don’t expect the same thing twice when you visit though – they offer a weekly changing menu according to which produce their local suppliers can offer.

Throughout Moss Vale and all of the Southern Highlands, there’s beautiful stores and eateries popping up regularly, and it has become a go-to destination for travellers, even just for a day trip to escape the bustling city.

While the people travel for the beautiful decor, kind staff and handcrafted organic meals, the locals stop by for their morning coffee and the sweets on offer – all are lovingly made in-house each day. Insiders tip – the doughnuts are always the first to sell out. If you ever come by and there are some left – be sure to grab one!

excerpt: Nestled just off Khyber Pass Road, L’Atelier du Fromage (which literally translates to The Cheese Shop) should be the next must-visit on your list.

If the baristas accent doesn’t confirm the authenticity of L’Atelier du Fromage, maybe the delicious french pastries that line the cabinet will. Locals favourite are the Croque-Monsieur, or if after something a bit heartier, the Saucisson Lyonnais (organic poached eggs, porcini mushroom sausages with agria potatoes).

Wanting to live up to the name, L’Atelier du Fromage also has an impressive cheese selection that would make any fromage connoisseur drool. Upstairs also houses a wide range of wines for you to take home and enjoy, after-hours.

title: George Cafe
excerpt: What was previously a hair salon has been gutted to create a now much-loved community hub in Tauranga, with a focus on fresh food.
content:
George opened their cafe doors in Autumn 2012 after their owners Claire & Luke turned their dream into a reality. By tackling the renovation with true Kiwi ingenuity, they were able to create a simple space where everything’s homemade – including the tables you sit at. With their priority always on fresh food, they took it a step further and utilised some beautiful land around the corner in Matapihi and have created a garden-to-table café of sorts.

By growing their own produce, they are able to keep down on costs as well as doing their bit to divert tonnes of waste from the landfill. They take anything that can break down – be it our compostable cups, coffee grinds or their vege scrap to the farm. The chooks start the process, the worms help out and then what’s left goes into hot composts. And after six months of patience, what’s left is beautiful, rich compost that can be put back into their soil.

Their hard working team is up at the crack of dawn – or even before – to begin the day. Making everything from scratch isn’t easy and their organic vegan croissant definitely isn’t going to bake itself!

From this philosophy of simple, homemade, handmade goods a community has organically begun to rally around them. It’s now the meeting point of choice for lots of locals and tourists alike. When we asked Claire what her favourite part of George has been, she said it’s been being able to see so many beautiful family, friends and relationships develop and grown.

title: Meshino
excerpt: Meshino is a sophisticated suburban café that has it all – great coffee, great food and great people. Sitting on a sunny Christchurch street, locals …
content:
Meshino is a sophisticated suburban café that has it all – great coffee, great food and great people. Sitting on a sunny Christchurch street, locals and visitors are easily drawn to this relaxed and friendly spot for their post-walk coffee or brunch with friends.

With meat and a variety of vegetables grown on the family farm, it’s no wonder Meshino has gained a loyal crowd of eaters and drinkers who enjoy the ever-changing seasonal menu, boutique wines and Allpress coffee available seven days a week.

title: Esplanade
excerpt: There is little more to say about Esplanade once you know the key details of its existence – it’s beachside, it’s Italian, and it’s based …
content:
There is little more to say about Esplanade once you know the key details of its existence – it’s beachside, it’s Italian, and it’s based in a beautiful  building in Saint Clair, Dunedin.  It speaks for itself, really.  But if we were going to say more, we’d tell you that its breakfast offering, made up of things like Crisp Fried Calzone, Toasted Sweet Fruit Panetone with Seasonal Fruit and Mascarpone and the Esplanade Breakfast of Sage-Fried Eggs, Prosciutto Cotto, Roast Tomato and Havoc Pork & Fennel Sausage might just pair beautifully with your morning Allpress hit as you sit in the stylish but friendly seaside spot.

And perhaps the dinner and dessert menu in all of its fresh pasta, pizza, Dark-Chocolate-Torta-Marscapone-Cherries glory might work quite harmoniously with a post-meal espresso.

gallery.caption: All images by Lisa Jane Photography, UK

title: Flotsam and Jetsam
excerpt: If you’re in London and on the lookout for a spot with good coffee, inviting food and happy people, then look no further – Flotsam …
content:
If you’re in London and on the lookout for a spot with good coffee, inviting food and happy people, then look no further – Flotsam and Jetsam is simply a great spot for a coffee, a bite to eat and a good old fashioned catch up.

A 5 minute walk from Wandsworth Common train station, Flotsam and Jetsam offers freshly baked pastries, Allpress coffee, a range of delicious drinks and a brunch menu that you’d be hard-pushed to not find your dream meal on. All set in a cosy and cool London location.

The menu changes with the seasons, but if Coco-Mango Bircher, Huevos Rancheros or F&J pancakes (American-style pancakes with crispy bacon, caramelised banana and mascarpone) are anything to go by, you should be pretty content whatever the weather.

subtitle: We originally started roasting coffee on Redchurch St in 2010, but slowly outgrew the space. Thankfully, we found a spacious old joiner’s factory and after restoring the previously derelict building, it is now the perfect home for us in London.
more_content:
The beating heart of Dalston Lane really is our Hot Air Roaster – ART III. Designed and built in New Zealand then shipped over to London to be reassembled – it’s a piece of art in itself. Our Hot Air Roaster allows us meticulous temperature control and stability over each roast, elevating natural sweetness to achieve a smooth taste, and the lasting flavour our coffee is known for.

In the café itself, we serve expertly prepared espresso or single origin filter brews. The food offering is simple with a selection of unique sandwiches, breakfast plates and canteen dishes for lunch.

If you’re heading off the beaten track, or just want to brew your morning coffee in the comfort of your own home – we can help you there too. Our freshly roasted blends are available to purchase and we can grind for whatever brew equipment you have on hand – be that a hipster Chemex, or a plunger that your nana gifted you thirty years ago.

title: London Roastery
excerpt: We took great pleasure bringing this working building back to life, and now it’s our UK base for roasting, technical support, barista training – and …
content:
We took great pleasure bringing this working building back to life, and now it’s our UK base for roasting, technical support, barista training – and serving locals a damn good coffee. Here, our work is designed to be seen – from loading the green bean silos to hand packing our blends – every stage of the roasting process is on show for you to enjoy while you have your morning brew. No secrets – just us, for all to see.

The building itself is spacious and radiant with natural light, and it reflects the character of our other spaces around the world. Just out of sight, on the sawtooth roof, we’ve fitted solar panels which power the Hot Air Roaster, coffee machines and everything in between.

title: No7 Balmac
excerpt: Nestled on Maori Hill, Dunedin all-day eatery No7 Balmac is dubbed fondly by its owners and its loyal customers as One Happy Restaurant. And this …
content:
Nestled on Maori Hill, Dunedin all-day eatery No7 Balmac is dubbed fondly by its owners and its loyal customers as One Happy Restaurant. And this self-awarded nick name couldn’t be more accurate. With great food, delicious coffee and an impressive wine list, a visit to No7 Balmac is bound to be a happy one.

And its location speaks to this too – a stylish yet relaxed building in a suburban spot just five minutes drive from the Dunedin city centre.

On the day menu at No7, you’ll find gems like Hummus with Garden Pesto, Spiced Chickpeas and Ciabatta or Cinnamon Brioche French Toast with Roasted Berries, Whipped Mascarpone and Honeycomb Dust.

And for later on, dishes like BBQ’d Free-Range Belly Pork with Cider-Braised Onions, Crushed Pea Jus and Woodgrilled Cauliflower with White Bean Mash, Sunflower Seed Pesto and Oyster Mushrooms sit among a broad range of delectable dishes using organic herbs, salad and greens from the No7 Balmac garden. One Happy Restaurant indeed.

subtitle: Located inside a contemporary art gallery, it’s a no-brainer that the fit-out of Lux Espresso is a piece of art in itself.

location.address: 66 Gloucester St, Christchurch Central, Christchurch 8013, New Zealand

title: Lux Espresso
excerpt: The vibrant city of Christchurch is on the up again, and this wee cafe is proof of just that. Fresh, simple and contemporary food selection, …
content:
The vibrant city of Christchurch is on the up again, and this wee cafe is proof of just that. Fresh, simple and contemporary food selection, paired with our Browns Mill Organic Blend through espresso makes this a great place to grab a bite with a friend, then carry on into the Christchurch Centre of Contemporary Art.

During the week it’s cabinet food only (not that that’s anything to cry about – the divine options really are endless), and there’s now a weekend menu about to be unveiled. They’re open seven days a week, and the tight-knit team at Lux Espresso encourage you to stay and learn about the art around you, or to sit at the bench to appreciate the exhibitions, and your delicious coffee, in peace.

subtitle: Plain Vanilla Bakery started as just that – a place to come and eat delicious, good old-fashioned cake. Only now, it’s slowly grown and turned into a bit more. Offering everything from flowers for your loved ones, spreads for the perfect ‘don’t-bring-anything’ gift, and even granola – to really get your day off to a sweet start.

location.address: 1D Yong Siak Street, Tiong Bahru Estate, Singapore 168641

title: Plain Vanilla Bakery
excerpt: Plain Vanilla Bakery isn’t here to do anything by halves. They believe in keeping recipes simple and using home baking traditions, paired with a good …
content:
Plain Vanilla Bakery isn’t here to do anything by halves. They believe in keeping recipes simple and using home baking traditions, paired with a good dose of heart. The team also know that no one can fault the timeless classic that is a plain vanilla cupcake.

Spread across three sites in Singapore, next time you’re nearby stop by for a coffee, stay for a caramel-swirled butter cake with salted caramel frosting, topped with a dollop of our homemade caramel and a sprinkling of Maldon sea salt flakes, and take home a gorgeous print from their Plain Vanilla Home range.

subtitle: The thriving Australian Café scene was inspiration enough for Kantaro and Naoya, the creative forces behind METoA Café & Kitchen.
title: METoA Café & Kitchen
excerpt: Located in Tokyu Plaza Ginza, the exterior of the building is made up entirely of glass, with the concept being – the world gets interesting …
content:
Located in Tokyu Plaza Ginza, the exterior of the building is made up entirely of glass, with the concept being – the world gets interesting from here. And that it does – they are lucky to be surrounded by a great mix of fashion, creative and other food outlets that bring like-minded customers into their café.

You can enjoy the Allpress Kiba Blend through espresso, or a rotating single origin brewed through a filter cone. For the food side of things, there’s something for everyone on the menu – including shared plates if you’re a bit peckish, BBQ chicken wings to nibble on, fresh pasta, homemade pancakes or, our favourite, the Pulled Pork Australian Pizzetta – think pork, gouda cheese, red onion, sprouts, chives topped with an egg, sunny-side up of course, all on a crisp base.

METoA Café & Kitchen is one to put on the list, and truly helping the café culture that we know and love seep into Tokyo’s everyday.

title: The Good Oil Cafe
excerpt: Dunedin, the fourth largest city in New Zealand, has a thriving café and restaurant scene – you can’t help but notice it as you walk …
content:
Dunedin, the fourth largest city in New Zealand, has a thriving café and restaurant scene – you can’t help but notice it as you walk down George Street. You also can’t help but notice the hive of activity that surrounds 314 George Street. That’s because that’s where Good Oil, a local community institution, proudly stands.

Jump at the opportunity if you ever come here and there’s a free seat, it’s a rare sighting. Their philosophy is simple – serve fresh, seasonal ingredients and the best espresso, just the way you like it.

To keep in with that philosophy, the menu doesn’t try too hard – there’s the crowd-favourite of roast mushrooms and wilted spinach on ciabatta, topped with a poached egg, a large selection of wraps and salads if you’re on-the-go, or if you’ve got more of a sweet-tooth then the baby lemon cakes are a must-try. Visit today and find out why their cinnamon rolls have got a cult-like status.

subtitle: Coffee and cycling go hand-in-hand, so we’ve always been proud of the Rapha connection we are lucky to have here at Allpress – it’s the commitment to quality and detail that align the brands so well.
opening_hours:
Mon to Fri – 10.30am to 8.30pm,

title: Rapha Cycle Club
excerpt: Located within walking distance from Osaka station, it’s an easy ride to get your next pick me up at the Rapha Cycle Club. .
content:
The café is the core of the club so offering customers with epicurean tastes the best coffee available was a key imperative.

Osaka Cycle Club’s renewal was designed by London based Brinkworth and houses a unique overhead bicycle storage solution among many other refinements, like the installation of the state of the art La Marzocco espresso machine in the newly updated café.

Located within walking distance from Osaka station, it’s an easy ride to get your next pick me up at the Rapha Cycle Club. Osaka is filled to the brim with cafes and restaurants – earning it’s name as the food capital of Japan. The city itself is bursting with personalities and a love of celebration. Rapha’s Cycle Club in Osaka should be a definite on everyone’s bucket list – cyclist or not.

subtitle: Redchurch St will always feel like our home in London.
more_content: Most of the shops in our nook of Shoreditch specialise in one single product: beard care, chocolate, perfume, handmade pasta… you name it. Our speciality is coffee; both to drink immediately, and to take home and brew in the comfort of your undies. Many of our locals have come to rely on us to supply you with your regular homebrew stash, and daily fix.

title: Redchurch Espresso Bar
excerpt: We opened our first Roastery here in 2010 and found a wonderfully eclectic community in the heart of Shoreditch. Thankfully, they welcomed us with open …
content:
We opened our first Roastery here in 2010 and found a wonderfully eclectic community in the heart of Shoreditch. Thankfully, they welcomed us with open arms and the rest is history.

When our lease came up in 2015, we took the chance to relocate our roastery to Dalston – bigger space and all that. But we couldn’t quite say goodbye to Redchurch St though, and moved down to the corner of Club Row and started serving Redchurch blend out of our busy little Espresso Bar.

subtitle:
This was the perfect home for our coffee, our people and our customers in Tokyo.
ここは私たちのコーヒー、チーム、そして東京の「ホーム」。
more_content:
We’ve been welcomed into the unique and ever-growing Kiyosumi Shirakawa neighbourhood with open arms. It’s a coffee-loving community that fosters creativity and new ideas. And one that allows young creative businesses to exist in symbiosis with those that have been here for decades, even centuries – a concept we couldn’t agree with more, really.

People, places and communities like this make it all worth that two year wait.

We look forward to welcoming you to our Tokyo Roastery & Café.
opening_hours:
Monday to Friday 8:00 - 17:00,
Saturday, Sunday and Public Holidays 9:00 - 18:00
title: Tokyo Roastery
excerpt: This was the perfect home for our coffee, our people and our customers in Tokyo.
content:
We spent over two years waiting for the perfect spot for our Tokyo Roastery to unveil itself. We knew what we wanted, but like all things Allpress, if it was going to be done, it was going to be done well.

In early 2013 whilst riding our bikes through Tokyo, we stopped and peered through the gaps of an old timber warehouse nestled in the serene Kiyosumi Shirakawa community. We saw the unique space before us – abandoned, with sunlight streaming in between the slats – and we instantly knew.

This was the perfect home for our coffee, our people and our customers in Tokyo.

東京のロースタリーにぴったりの場所が見つかるまで、２年以上の時間をかけました。私たちが求めるものははっきりしていましたし、やるからにはきちんとやりたかったのです。

2013年はじめ、東京の街なかで自転車を走らせていたとき、私たちはふと立ち止まって、清澄白河の静かな住宅街の中にある古い木造の倉庫を見つめました。木の壁から中を覗いてみると、そこには変わった空間 – 廃屋の中に木の板の隙間から日差しが差し込む光景 – があり、それを見た瞬間、私たちは確信しました。この場所こそ私たちのコーヒー、社員、そしてお客さまにとって最高の場所であると。

After rebuilding the following year, the Tokyo Roastery & Café now stands as a carefully restored space that infuses a celebration of its past with an exciting nod to the future. These days, not only is our Tokyo spot a place for us to roast beautiful coffee for our wholesale customers, but it’s a welcoming spot for people to gather, connect and converse. The Allpress way. Floor to ceiling windows between the high ceilings of the roastery and café create a working industrial atmosphere so that each area feels part of the other and there is a strong sense of connectivity throughout.

After enjoying a coffee in the Tokyo café, there is an open invite to all visitors to learn about what is going on behind the glass in our roastery. The space also doubles as a home for our technical, training and sales team. A hub of knowledge and activity that we’re proud to call ours.

翌年の改築で東京ロースタリー＆カフェは丁寧にリノベーションされ、過去の美しい時代とエキサイティングな未来が融合する場所として生まれ変わりました。それからと言うもの、この東京の店は卸売のコーヒー豆を焙煎する場所というだけでなく、人が集まり、つながり、そして会話を弾ませるあたたかい場所になりました。これこそがオールプレスが目指す姿です。一面のガラス仕切りで隔てられるカフェエリアと天井が高いロースタリーは、インダストリアルな雰囲気のなか、それぞれが互いの一部分かのように機能しており、全体のつながりを強く意識させる造りとなっています。

subtitle: When The Roadhouse opened their doors in 2012, they wanted to create a place that their friends and family could come and enjoy. It’s fair to say they’ve succeeded those expectations and even done a bit more, earning themselves a well-deserved place on the must-visit list while in Byron Bay.
opening_hours:
Coffee: 6.30am – 2pm 7 days,
Brunch: 7am – 1.30pm 7 days,
Dinner: 6pm – 10pm Tuesday-Saturday
title: The Roadhouse Byron Bay
excerpt: The group of mates who work (and play) at the Roadhouse are lucky that there is an abundance of farmers and distributors around Byron producing …
content:
The group of mates who work (and play) at the Roadhouse are lucky that there is an abundance of farmers and distributors around Byron producing delicious artisan goods. By focusing on using local, organic produce it means that their Hunters & Gathers board changes daily. From flame tail snapper, white bean salsa with avocado and jalapeño cream, to Roadhouse Ramen with rare wagyu, soba noodles, steamed veg, pickles, boiled egg, seaweed and togarashi. If there’s one thing that we can promise, it’s that one meal at The Roadhouse is never the same as the next.

The space itself was nothing more than a tin roof when the team arrived but they transformed it into a warm, inviting and friendly space where you’ll see bearded hipsters rubbing shoulders with suits and plenty of barefoot-surfers – all coming in for their morning pick me up.

subtitle: Once an abandoned warehouse, our beautiful roastery on Rupert Street is our home in Melbourne.
more_content:
In our ongoing quest for the perfect cup, we’ve learnt that every quality bean has promise and it’s the roast method that truly delivers on a beans potential. We took the aspiration for roasting perfection the next level in Melbourne and built ART II, our second Hot Air Roaster, from the ground up. The benefits of Allpress Hot Air Roast Method are in the cup – it elevates natural sweetness to achieve a smooth taste, and gives the lasting flavour Allpress Espresso is known for.

Glass windows separate office space from roasting space; and cupping room from barista training room leaving sight lines open from the Roastery Café to reveal this work zone from where fresh coffee is supplied to local cafes.

Our Melbourne Roastery is a place where we invite you to learn more about coffee, about how to brew coffee, and where you can learn first-hand the Allpress difference.
title: Melbourne Roastery
excerpt: Once an abandoned warehouse, our beautiful roastery on Rupert Street is now our home in Melbourne.
content:
From the beginning, repurposing derelict buildings has always been the Allpress way and our Melbourne Roastery was no different.  The beauty of Rupert Street is it’s original design was able to be fully restored and utilised. Housed under the south facing sawtooth roof is our roastery, café, offices and many tools from our technical team – an exciting, all-encompassing hub for our customers, coffee drinkers and teams in Melbourne.

Collingwood is increasingly becoming a destination café for people looking for a tasty lunch in the sun and our roastery café offers a chance for just that. It’s also our only space that has a outdoor courtyard with planting designed to bring green tranquility into the urban industrial setting for you to find a quiet spot to think, relax and recharge.

We pride ourselves as espresso specialists, so stick to a simple menu of espresso based coffees. However, we welcome the time spent with customers when making a pour over or offering cold brew in the summer months. A small selection of food items makes up the canteen style menu, showcasing fresh seasonal ingredients.

subtitle: Byron Bay, the bustling coastal town in NSW, is home to our latest espresso bar. Inspired by our other spaces around the world, we’ve created an integrated home for customers and coffee drinkers alike to truly become apart of the action. It’s a place where we can take the time to connect, the time to educate and, most of all, the time to create lasting relationships.
